lexUnit.name: reproach.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a feeling of disapproval or disappointment.

sentence.text: ` Nowadays " , said Bismarck in 1884 , ` no Government is strong enough to stand the reproach of having sacrificed its own national interests as a favour to a friendly Power . "
However , if I do think of myself as making a considered choice , can I deny the justice of your reproach ?
Her reproach was lost on Richard for he was only half .
The argument against poststructuralism really just repeats Lukács ' reproach , set out in his 1957 essay ‘ The Ideology of Modernism ’ , that modernism involves a ‘ negation of history ’ .
She is as careful as a chemist with her reproaches .
So , ignoring Mala 's reproaches , I took myself back to my cabin and the galacvid 's more entertaining screen material .
His quiet reproaches , as I had felt on more than one occasion , were all the more devastating .
At no time , either , did Zacco either seek to be alone with him , or utter a word of reproach about his failure with Famagusta .

But as soon as I begin to be nice to him , a sort of self-satisfaction seems to creep into his voice and his manner ( very discreet , he 's been humility itself all day , no reproach about last night , of course ) and I begin to want to goad and slap him again .
Mrs Baggley 's pastoral tone was full of reproach at Theodora 's lack of finer feeling in this area .
Stephen Duck and Mary Collier , however , both describe reproaches from a master or mistress .
With bands like Nirvana , the Pixies and My Bloody Valentine beyond reproach from the music press and the record-buying public there has never been a better time to play guitars with manic fervour .
Occasionally he hated her for it , because he took it to be a reproach of himself .
He stands adamant , a living reproach to all others in the circle of brethren .
Paul saw this as a reproach to himself , as if he had not shown enough interest ; perhaps in fact he had not ; his heart had never been in it .
The Zuckerman books help one to imagine how Roth has faced the reproach that he has derided his family and sold their secrets .
` Indeed , but for my brother 's tears , his reproaches that I had not drawn my sword , I would have dismissed the whole affair as a nightmare . "
For one thing , he made it a reproach that Anselm 's ` election " had been the work of schismatics -- a charge which Anselm coldly denied .
On release she went to the mayor and so powerful were her reproaches that he ` acknowledged the truth of her doctrine " and henceforth attempted to protect Quakers .
I was n't sure if this was a reproach that he deserted her the rest of the year .

Above all , fidelity to the " open justice " principle keeps Britain free from the reproach that it permits " secret courts " of the kind which have been instruments of repression in so many other countries .
Perhaps it was one of those impetuous decisions that were always earning me reproaches , but it was also a logical step because of my interests .
